content: Can you provide me with the XML code that explains the metaphorical usage of the phrase "raining cats and dogs" and its origins in 17th-century English literature?

Creating an XML document to explain the metaphorical usage and origins of the phrase "raining cats and dogs" involves structuring the information in a way that is both descriptive and informative. Below is an example of how such an XML document could be structured:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<phrase>
    <expression>Raining Cats and Dogs</expression>
    <type>Metaphor</type>
    <description>
        The phrase "raining cats and dogs" is a common English idiom used to describe a very heavy rain. It is metaphorical and does not have a literal meaning.
    </description>
    <origin>
        <timePeriod>17th Century</timePeriod>
        <literature>
            <author>Jonathan Swift</author>
            <work>Complete Collection of Genteel and Ingenious Conversation</work>
            <year>1738</year>
        </literature>
        <explanation>
            The exact origin of the phrase is unclear, but it is believed to have been popularized in the 17th century. One theory suggests that it may have originated from the Greek expression "cata doxa," which means "contrary to experience or belief," or from Norse mythology, where cats and dogs were associated with storms.
        </explanation>
    </origin>
    <culturalSignificance>
        The phrase has been used historically to convey the intensity of storms and is still commonly used in modern English vernacular to describe heavy rainfall.
    </culturalSignificance>
    <examples>
        <example>
            "Don't forget your umbrella; it's raining cats and dogs outside!"
        </example>
    </examples>
</phrase>
```

This XML document describes the metaphorical usage of the phrase, its historical origins, and its cultural significance. Of course, interpretations of idioms and their origins can vary, and historical documentation can sometimes be sparse or speculative.
